name: methyl_butyl_ether
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: 1,3-dioxolane has a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius. The basic unit, ethylene, has a melting point of -109.4 degrees Celsius. The methyl group introduces a rigid structure, which can participate in hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point by approximately +10 degrees Celsius. The butyl group introduces additional molecular weight and van der Waals forces, raising the melting point by approximately +20 degrees Celsius. The dioxane-like bridging moiety adds rigidity and likely contributes more significantly than a simple ether, estimated at around +5 degrees Celsius for this structural feature.
